name: cobalt production | nickel, class 1 | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/23006/documentation

This dataset represents the production of cobalt by the global cobalt industry. Reference: "The Environmental Performance of Refined Cobalt - Life Cycle Inventory and Life Cycle Assessment of Refined Cobalt - Summary Report", CDI & ERM, Novermber 2016. PM2.5-10 and PM10 emissions to air arise from mine ventillation systems.

This activity starts from cradle (i.e. including all upstream activities) inclusing the extraction of ore and the collection of secondary material)

This activity ends at factory gate with the refined cobalt metal. This dataset includes activities related to mining (surface and underground extraction), beneficiation (production of concentrate and/or raffinate solution), primary extraction (selection and further concentration of cobalt), and refining (refining into cobalt metals).
category: C:Manufacturing/24:Manufacture of basic metals/242:Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals/2420:Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The data has been collected from a globally representative sample of companies in the cobalt industry.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Cobalt, as a co-product of nickel and copper production, is obtained using a wide range of technologies. The initial life cycle stage covers the mining of the ore through underground or open cast methods. The ore is further processed in beneficiation to produce a concentrate and/or raffinate solution. Metal selection and further concentration is initiated in primary extraction, which may involve calcining, smelting, high pressure leaching, and other processes. The final product is obtained through further refining, which may involve processes such as re-leaching, selective solvent / solution extraction, selective precipitation, electrowinning, and other treatments. Transport is reported separately and consists of only the internal movements of materials / intermediates, and not the movement of final product. Due to its intrinsic value, cobalt has a high recycling rate. However, much of this recycling takes place downstream through the recycling of alloy scrap into new alloy, or goes into the cobalt chemical sector as an intermediate requiring additional refinement. Secondary production, ie production from the recycling of cobalt-containing wastes, is considered in this study in so far as it occurs as part of the participating companiesâ€™ production. This was shown to be of very limited significance (less than 1% of cobalt inputs). The secondary materials used for producing cobalt are modelled as entering the system free of environmental burden.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: The project has a reference period of year 2012. Primary, site-specific, data for cobalt production were collected for the calendar year 2012, or the nearest 12 month period for which data were available. In some cases, this meant 2013 data were provided. The reason for the flexibility was to allow for easier data collection for companies where company reporting periods do not follow the calendar year. In selecting the chosen reference period, it was assumed, and confirmed by the participating companies, that no major disruptions to operations or technology changes happened during the data collection period.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Questionnaires were sent to 8 major cobalt producers and responses were received.

exchanges.description: Value obtained from the industry. The amount is split between the different reference products based on their cobalt content.

flow.name: Nickel II
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to water/surface water

exchanges.description:
Represents the flows that go to neutralization:
Acid condensate effluent: 0.00788697088950315 m3
Acid condensate effluent: 0.000128671718251306 kg
Leach residue: 4.64144694131532 kg
Waste solution: 0.00169088729044507 m3

The flows expressed in m3 are converted to kg using a density value of 1084 kg/m3 (Dannenberg et al. 1987).

The amount is split between the different reference products based on their cobalt content.

References:
R. O. Dannenberg, P. C. Gardner, S. R. Crane, and D. C. Seidel (1987). Recovery of Cobalt and Copper From Complex Sulfide Concentrates. Bureau of Mines, Report of Investigations.
